answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Lee,
Here are a few documents that should be useful to you.
A White paper from the New Jersey State Association of Chiefs of Police on regionalization and merger considerations for policy makers includes a section on labor agreements. 
http://www.bergencountypolicechiefs.org/sacop/WhitePaper-Consolidation.pdf 
The Police & Communications Regionalization Analysis for the Towns of Ashby and Townsend, MA discusses the possible complexities of employee benefits and procedures in collective bargaining agreements. 
http://www.ci.ashby.ma.us/document/Ashby_Townsend_Reg_MAP.pdf
A case study on merger of the Metropolitan Government of Louisville- Jefferson County, KY provides the labor strategy adopted during the merger. 
https://fm.pfm.com/default.aspx/ctrl/Default/nodeID/3ea0731d-c879-4c7e-82cd-4a405df7bf68 
The Benton County, Oregon report highlights the labor issues during the Law enforcement consolidation.   
http://www.ci.corvallis.or.us/downloads/cmo/lewhitepaper.pdf
You may also wish to contact the departments for further information. 
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja 
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

answers.author: William Gilmore
answers.text:
Lee, just some advice from what I’ve seen when regional strategies were proposed.  The best results for integration to a county-wide service delivery strategy is to take the time in the beginning to discuss the vision of what a leading edge police force could look like if they could meet specific benchmarks five to ten years out.  Come at this from the perspective of a Cities of the Future concept.  The reason being that you know what you have today but will that be effective for the next generation of socially connected communities that will have more stay at home businesses, more urban oriented redevelopment that support sustainable community concepts, greater reliance on security systems (location cameras, red light cameras, building security, and so on), and will community policing strategies with more on the ground (bicycles, walking) not vehicle based roaming teams that advocate more enhanced community relations be part of this solution?   
I am an advocate for regional solutions and encourage you to proceed aggressively in performing a visioning exercise that will meet your county’s “stretch goals” and progressive expectations ten years out.  Setting these goals early will allow you to plan to establish a broader foundation from which to build add-ons to your existing strategy from inception.  It will also set expectations early so that decisions to revise job descriptions, possibly expand the non-uniformed staff to fill certain community relations goals, and potentially leverage the business community by understanding their expectations so they can advocate your goals to the broader public, you will have more support behind the county’s plans and a greater chance of success.   
Finally, when it comes to the labor agreements, if you have the vision document before you when you begin negotiating policy, service levels, coverage, IT systems requirements, and 10 year goals with union staff regarding qualifications, skill levels, and training expectations to achieve the future county vision, the dynamics of that discussion will be more in managements favor.   
I hope you find this helpful. 
Bill Gilmore 
William B. Gilmore, LLC 
email:  gilmorewb1@gmail.com

author: Lee Honecker
text: I am on a countywide task force investigating the regionalization of municipal police departments into one department and need any advice available on integration of labor contracts.  Does anyone have advice or examples inthis area?
title: Police Regionalization
